title-group.article-title: Robotic versus laparoscopic total gastrectomy for gastric cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis of perioperative and oncologic outcomes

The work cannot be changed in any way or used commercially without permission from the journal.

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: While robotic total gastrectomy (RTG) has gained traction in minimally invasive gastric cancer surgery, high-level evidence comparing its efficacy with laparoscopic total gastrectomy (LTG) remains limited. This systematic review and meta-analysis aimed to comprehensively evaluate the comparative efficacy and safety of RTG versus LTG in gastric cancer patients, thereby informing evidence-based surgical decision-making.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We systematically searched PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library, and Web of Science databases from inception until November 2024 for comparative studies of RTG and LTG. Perioperative outcomes (intraoperative blood loss, severe complications [Clavien–Dindo grade ≥3], abdominal infection rates, postoperative hospitalization) and oncologic parameters (retrieved lymph nodes, 3-year overall survival [OS], disease-free survival [DFS]) were analyzed. Risk ratios and weighted mean differences (WMD) with 95% confidence intervals were calculated. Protocol registered with PROSPERO.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The results revealed that RTG significantly reduced severe complications (CD ≥3), abdominal infection, intraoperative blood loss, and postoperative hospital stay compared to LTG. Additionally, RTG led to an increased number of retrieved lymph nodes. However, no significant differences were observed in 3-year OS and DFS between RTG and LTG, consistent with findings from other types of gastrectomy. The subgroup analysis demonstrated that the use of linear staplers was more effective in reducing severe complications and postoperative hospital stay.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: RTG confers superior perioperative safety profiles compared to LTG while maintaining equivalent oncologic outcomes. The technical advantages of robotic platforms – particularly enhanced instrument maneuverability in narrow spaces – may explain reduced intraoperative trauma and complication risks. These findings support RTG as a viable option for centers with robotic expertise, though cost-effectiveness analyses remain warranted.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Gastric cancer is one of the most common malignant tumors worldwide, with both incidence and mortality rates ranking among the highest globally. According to the Global Cancer Statistics[1], gastric cancer ranks fifth in terms of incidence and fourth in terms of mortality worldwide, with particularly high rates in East Asia. Despite the advances in technology in recent years, with various treatment options such as immunotherapy[2,3], chemotherapy[4], and radiotherapy[5], surgery remains the main treatment modality. However, controversy still exists regarding the choice of surgical approach[6]. To date, global guidelines have not reached a consensus on the optimal method of lymphadenectomy. The Japanese guidelines tend to recommend D2 lymphadenectomy, while Western guidelines are more inclined toward D1 lymphadenectomy[7–9]. In total gastrectomy, esophagojejunostomy is the most technically demanding procedure and is also the primary cause of anastomotic leakage. Various techniques, such as the overlap anastomosis and π anastomosis, have been employed worldwide. However, the optimal anastomotic method remains undetermined[10].

The advent of robotic-assisted surgery has revolutionized minimally invasive gastrointestinal oncology since Hashizume’s pioneering robotic gastrectomy in 2002[11]. Contemporary robotic platforms (e.g. da Vinci Xi System) address critical limitations of conventional laparoscopy through enhanced dexterity (7° articulating instruments), tremor filtration, and immersive three-dimensional visualization[12–14] – attributes particularly advantageous in complex dissections such as suprapancreatic lymph node stations (No. 7, 8a, 9) and esophagojejunal anastomosis[15,16]. Over the past decade, robotic gastrectomy has evolved from an exploratory approach to a standardized procedure, with an increasing body of evidence supporting its safety, feasibility, and oncological efficacy[17–19].

At the same time, comparisons between robotic surgery and laparoscopic surgery have become a research focus[20,21]. Total gastrectomy is one of the most challenging procedure in gastric cancer surgery, and the high precision of robotic surgery compensates for the limitations of laparoscopic surgery. Robotic assistance can significantly reduce the steep learning curve associated with complex procedures such as laparoscopic total gastrectomy (LTG), thereby enabling physicians without extensive laparoscopic expertise to perform these operations[22]. Current guidelines express optimism regarding robotic gastrectomy. As technology continues to advance, future gastric cancer surgeries are expected to become increasingly minimally invasive, potentially leveraging rapidly evolving robotic technologies. But, there are still significant gaps in the comparative study of robotic total gastrectomy (RTG) and LTG. Most of the existing meta-analyses included cases of non-total gastrectomy, and there was a lack of long-term oncology outcomes[19]. The robot system has great advantages in complex anatomy and precision operation in narrow space. It is theoretically highly suitable for complex surgeries such as total gastrectomy. However, its actual benefits still need to be supported by targeted evidence. To clarify the efficacy of RTG, the systematic review and meta-analysis addresses this unmet need through rigorous comparison of robotic versus LTG (RTG vs. LTG), with particular emphasis on lymph node harvest adequacy, anastomotic complications, and long-term functional outcomes.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p:
In conducting this meta-analysis, we defined the research question on the basis of the PICOS framework to ensure the systematic and transparent nature of the study (Supplemental Digital Content Table S1, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417). We followed the PRISMA 2020 checklist (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Evaluations and Meta-Analyses) and the AMSTAR-2 guidelines, the MOOSe checklist, and the TITAN guidelines 2025 (Supplemental Digital Content Table S2 available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417, which pertain to declaration and use of artificial intelligence) to determine the accuracy of the methods[23–26]. This study is registered in PROSPERO.HIGHLIGHTS
Robotic total gastrectomy (RTG) demonstrated superiority over laparoscopic total gastrectomy (LTG) in the perioperative period, with notable improvements in key clinical outcomes.
Linear staplers proved superior to circular staplers in achieving reductions in postoperative hospital stay and lowering rates of complications classified as Clavien–Dindo grade≥3.
The RTG group exhibited a significantly higher number of lymph nodes harvested compared to the LTG group, highlighting the potential benefits of robotic surgery in lymph node dissection.

sec.title: Search strategy
sec.p: The Pubmed, Embase, Cochrane Library, and Web of Science databases were searched from the time of construction to November 2024, and we searched the above databases using the subject terms Gastrectomy, Robotic Surgical Procedures, Laparoscopy and the corresponding free words in English only. Clinical Trial Registration Platform in the USA, China, EU, UK, Germany, Japan, and Korea were searched and we searched the above databases by using keywords total gastrectomy. For details of the search strategy, please see Supplemental Digital Content Tables S3 and S4, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417.

sec.title: Study selection
sec.p: The study selection process was conducted by two authors according to predetermined inclusion and exclusion criteria. Both authors used EndnoteX9 to complete the literature screening process and removed duplicate and irrelevant articles based on title and abstract. Subsequently, the full text of potentially eligible articles was obtained and the full text was carefully read to ensure inclusion of all relevant studies. Any discrepancies that arose during the evaluation were resolved by consulting a third researcher, and the relevant articles were discussed until a consensus was reached.

sec.title: Inclusion and exclusion criteria
sec.p: The inclusion criteria were created based on the PICOS strategy

sec.title: Data extraction
sec.p: Data extraction was carried out independently by two authors, with disagreements resolved by discussion with the other author. Information collected included: study characteristics: first author, time of publication, study design, country, sample size, mean age, gender. Clinical characteristics: type of lymph node dissection, digestive tract reconstruction, stapler type, follow-up time, tumor stage; Outcome metrics: primary outcome metrics included OS and disease-free survival (DFS) at 3 years. The remaining outcome indicators included number of lymph nodes cleared and postoperative complications, postoperative hospital stay, intraoperative bleeding, operative time, time to first exhaust, pulmonary infection, anastomotic leakage, abdominal infection and abdominal bleeding.

sec.title: Quality assessment
sec.p: The quality of case-control study and cohort study was defined by the Newcastle–Ottawa Quality Assessment Scale[27]. The quality of each study was assessed independently by two researchers. The quality of evidence was assessed by the GRADE tool[28], by two authors and any disagreement was resolved by discussion or the third reviewer.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Stata 17.0 software was used to analyze the data. Dichotomous variables were assessed using the risk ratio (RR) and the weighted mean difference (WMD) was calculated for continuous variables. I2 and chi-square test were used to assess statistical heterogeneity. Given the inherent variability in patient characteristics, surgical techniques, and institutional protocols, all indexes were analyzed by random effects model. At the same time, we also adopted the fixed-effect model for indicators with the I2 less than 50%. If the direction of the two effect models is consistent, the results are stable. Forest plots were considered statistically significant when the P-value was <0.05. For studies with only median and extreme deviation or interquartile range, we converted the data to mean and standard deviation according to Wan et al[29]. To avoid publication bias, funnel plots, and Egger’s tests were used. If the P-value of the Egger test is less than 0.05, we use the trimmed method to correct and evaluate the publication bias. For sources of heterogeneity, sensitivity analyses, and subgroup analyses were performed to verify the stability of the primary outcome. If survival data were provided with HR and 95% confidence intervals (CI), we directly extracted the data for meta-analysis. Otherwise, if the survival data is shown as a Kaplan–Meier survival curve, we use the Engauge digitizer (version 4.1) to estimate HR and 95% CI, and to reconstruct HR and standard error (SE).

sec.title: Literature search
sec.p:
A total of 1417 documents were searched from database from construction to November 2024. After removing duplicates, 1082 articles were obtained. After initial screening through title and abstract review and full-text reading a total of 15 papers were included in the meta-analysis. The reasons for exclusion were as follows: abstract only, irrelevant results, experiment in progress, not published in English, and duplicated data (Fig. 1). A total of 290 clinical trial registrations were retrieved. Five trial records met the inclusion criteria after title and full text screening. Figure 1.
Flowchart of the study screening and evaluation process.

sec.title: Study characteristics
sec.p:
The clinical characteristics of all the study articles included in the Meta-analysis are shown in Table 1. Overall, 15 papers with a total of 2240 patients were included in the study. These studies were conducted in China (7), Korea (4), and Japan (4). The characteristics of the registration records of the five trials that met the inclusion criteria are shown in Supplemental Digital Content Table S5, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417. NCT05235982 and NCT03524300 are RCTs conducted in China, however they have not been published and no results have been released. Table 1

sec.title: Quality assessment
sec.p:
The quality of the included studies is shown in Table 2. For cohort studies and case-control studies, we use NOS to assess the quality of the studies. Studies with a score of ≥7 on the NOS indicate that the studies are of sufficiently high quality to be included in the meta-analysis. Table 2

sec.title: The primary outcome (long-term survival indicates)
sec.p:
Six papers reported the 3-year overall survival rate in the RTG group versus the LTG group, with no heterogeneity across studies (I2 = 0, P = 0.867). The result shows that the 3-year overall survival rate was similar between the two groups (HR = 0.795, 95% CI: 0.564–1.119, P = 0.289) (Fig. 2A). Five papers reported the 3-year DFS rate in the RTG group versus the LTG group, with no heterogeneity across studies (I2 = 0, P = 0.742). The results suggest that the 3-year DFS rate was similar between the two groups (HR = 0.771, 95% CI: 0.476–1.247, P = 0.289) (Fig. 2B). Figure 2.
Forest plot of the meta-analysis for 3-year overall survival and disease-free survival. (A) 3-year overall survival. (B) 3-year disease-free survival.

sec.title: Surgical outcomes
sec.p:
Eleven papers reported the operation time, with high heterogeneity across studies (I2 = 76.4%, P = 0.000). The operative time was significantly increased in the RTG group with an average increase of 32.642 min (WMD = 32.642, 95% CI: 22.539–42.746, P = 0.000) compared to LTG group (Fig. 3A). Figure 3.
Forest plot of the meta-analysis for surgical outcomes. (A) Operation time. (B). Total number of lymph node dissection. (C) Number of metastatic lymph node dissection. (D) Intraoperative blood loss.

Eleven papers reported the total number of lymph node dissection, with low heterogeneity across studies (I2 = 19.2%, P = 0.261). The total number of lymph node dissection was significantly increased in the RTG group with an average increase of 3.369 (WMD = 3.369, 95% CI: 2.211–4.526, P = 0.000) compared to LTG group (Fig. 3B).

Two papers reported the number of metastatic lymph node dissection, with no heterogeneity among the studies (I2 = 0, P = 0.943), The results suggest that the number of metastatic lymph node dissection was no statistically significant difference between the two groups (WMD = 0.705, 95% CI: −0.614 to 2.023, P = 0.295) (Fig. 3C).

Eight papers reported the intraoperative blood loss in the RTG group versus the LTG group, with low heterogeneity among the studies (I2 = 5.1%, P = 0.391). The intraoperative blood loss was significantly reduced in the RTG group with an average reduction of 18.168 mL (WMD = −18.103, 95% CI: −23.085 to −13.122, P = 0.000), compared to LTG group (Fig. 3D).

sec.title: Postoperative outcomes
sec.p:
Ten papers reported the postoperative hospital stay in the RTG group versus the LTG group, with high heterogeneity across studies (I2 = 62.2%, P = 0.005). The results show that RTG group resulted in an average reduction of 0.769 days (WMD = −0.769, 95% CI: −1.469 to −0.06, P = 0.032), compared to LTG groups (Fig. 4A). Figure 4.
Forest plot of the meta-analysis for postoperative outcomes. (A) Postoperative hospital stay. (B) The first exhaust time.

Five papers reported the first exhaust time in the RTG group versus the LTG group, with high heterogeneity across studies (I2 = 81.6%, P = 0.005). The result shows that the first exhaust time no statistically significant difference between the two groups (WMD = −0.275, 95% CI: −0.662–0.112, P = 0.164) (Fig. 4B).

sec.title: Complications
sec.p:
Twelve papers reported the overall postoperative complication rates in the RTG and LTG groups, with no heterogeneity among the studies (I2 = 0, P = 0.991). The results show that no statistically significant difference between the two groups (RR = 0.908, 95% CI: 0.762–1.082, P = 0.282) (Fig. 5A). Figure 5.
Forest plot of the meta-analysis for complications. (A) Overall postoperative complication rates. (B) Clavien–Dindo classification ≥3 rates. (C) Intra-abdominal bleeding rates. (D) The ileus. (E) Pulmonary infection rates, (F) Abdominal infection rates. (G) Anastomotic leakage rates.

Thirteen papers reported the Clavien–Dindo classification ≥3 rates in the RTG and LTG groups, with low heterogeneity among the studies (I2 = 6.4%, P = 0.382). Lower rate of Clavien–Dindo classification ≥3 was found in RTG group (RR = 0.647, 95% CI: 0.443–0.945, P = 0.024) compared to LTG group (Fig. 5B).

Nine papers reported the intra-abdominal bleeding rates in the RTG and LTG groups, with no heterogeneity among the studies (I2 = 0, P = 0.908). The results show that no statistically significant difference between the two groups (RR = 0.819, 95% CI: 0.375–1.790, P = 0.617) (Fig. 5C).

Seven papers reported ileus in the RTG and LTG groups, with no heterogeneity among the studies (I2 = 0, P = 0.965). The results show that similar ileus rates between the two groups (RR = 1.045, 95% CI: 0.552–1.977, P = 0.892) (Fig. 5D).

Nine papers reported the pulmonary infection rates in the RTG and LTG groups, with no heterogeneity among the studies (I2 = 0, P = 0.595). The results show that no statistically significant difference between the two groups (RR = 0.781, 95% CI: 0.508–1.202, P = 0.262) (Fig. 5E).

Six papers reported the abdominal infection rates in the RTG and LTG groups, with no heterogeneity among the studies (I2 = 0, P = 0.881). Lower rate of abdominal infection was found in RTG group (RR = 0.270, 95% CI: 0.131–0.716, P = 0.006) (Fig. 5F).

Twelve papers reported the anastomotic leakage rates in the RTG and LTG groups, with no heterogeneity among the studies (I2 = 0, P = 0.880). The results show that no statistically significant difference between the two groups (RR = 0.729, 95% CI: 0.411–1.290, P = 0.277) (Fig. 5G).

sec.title: Total cost
sec.p:
Three papers reported the total cost, with high heterogeneity among the studies (P = 0.130, I2 = 50.9%). The total cost was significantly increased in the RTG group with an average increase of 3222.231$ (WMD = 3222.231, 95% CI: 2487.511–3956.951, P = 0.000) compared to LTG group (Fig. 6). Figure 6.
Forest plot of the meta-analysis for total cost.

sec.title: Subgroup analysis
sec.p:
Subgroup analyses were performed based on stapler type, esophagojejunostomy, and country. Detailed results can be found in Tables 3 and 4 and Supplemental Digital Content Table S6, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417. Since some articles did not report corresponding indicators, we assigned them to the NA group for subgroup analysis. For the stapler subgroup, we are divided into three groups: circular stapler, linear stapler, and multiple stapler. Multiple staplers refer to the use of different types of staplers and it is difficult to determine clinical significance, so we report on circular stapler group and linear stapler group. For the esophagojejunostomy subgroup, we reported the end-to-end anastomosis group, the side-to-side anastomosis group and π – shaped/FEEA/overlap group. Overall, the use of linear staplers was more effective in reducing postoperative hospital stay duration and the incidence of complications graded as Clavien–Dindo ≥3. In subgroup of stapler, the results for the remaining indicators were consistent with the original findings (Supplemental Digital Content Figure S1). In subgroup of esophagojejunostomy π – shaped/FEEA/overlap group was more effective in reducing of complications graded as Clavien–Dindo ≥3 (Supplemental Digital Content Figure S2, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417). In subgroup of country, Japan group was more effective in reducing of complications graded as Clavien–Dindo ≥3 (Supplemental Digital Content Figure S3, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417). sec.title: Publication of bias and level of evidence
sec.p:
Funnel plot and Egger’s test were used to detect publication bias. Apart from the operation time (P = 0.019), where the regression line slope was significant and the 95% CI for the intercept did not include zero, indicating the potential presence of publication bias, all other outcome measures did not demonstrate evidence of publication bias (P > 0.05) (Fig. 7A). For the operation time, a trim-and-fill analysis was conducted, which revealed that the effect sizes remained unchanged before and after trimming, and the results still have statistical significance (Fig. 7B). This finding indicates that the impact of publication bias was minimal, rendering the results robust (Supplemental Digital Content Figure S4, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417). We assessed the level of evidence for the results of the meta-analysis using the GRADE system (Supplemental Digital Content Table S7, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417).Figure 7.
(A) Egger’s test plot for operating time. (B) Funnel plot with the trim-and-fill method for operating time.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis and meta-regression
sec.p: We conducted a sensitivity analysis to assess the stability of the outcome indicators. The results showed that when the studies by Jia et al[32], Chen et al[34], Shibasaki et al[36], and Kumamoto et al[39] were excluded, there was no significant difference in the postoperative hospital stay between the RTG group and the LTG group (Supplemental Digital Content Figure S5A, B, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417). This shows that the results for postoperative hospital stay were unstable. For the remaining indicators, the results remained consistent and stable after sequentially excluding each study. For indicators with I2 ≤ 50%, we also used the fixed-effect model to analysis, and the results were consistent with the random-effect model, indicating that the results were stable (Supplemental Digital Content Figure S6, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417). We used meta-regression to explore the sources of heterogeneity. The results of the meta-regression showed that the P-values of age, region, and publication year for the operation time were 0.483, 0.241, and 0.023, the P-values for the postoperative hospital stay were 0.309, 0.084, and 0.881. This indicates that the publication year is the source of the heterogeneity of operation time (Supplemental Digital Content Figure S7, available at: http://links.lww.com/JS9/E417).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: As a hot research field, robotic surgery has produced a large number of meta-analyses on robotic gastrectomy[45,46]. However, research on RTG is still limited. This study comprehensively compared the efficacy of RTG and traditional LTG, and included high-quality studies to provide evidence-based clinical support. The results showed that although RTG prolonged the operation time, it significantly reduced grade CD ≥3 complications, abdominal infection, intraoperative blood loss, and postoperative hospital stay, and increased the number of lymph nodes removed, indicating that RTG was superior to LTG in short-term prognosis.

The long-term survival rate is the key index to evaluate the effect of tumor treatment. The results of this study showed no significant differences between RTG and LTG in terms of three-year OS and DFS. This result is consistent with meta-analyses of other types of gastrectomy[47–49]. Although RTG showed advantages in the short term, these advantages failed to translate into improved tumor treatment outcomes. This suggests that surgical technique alone may not be a key factor in long-term survival. A number of studies in the field of gastric cancer have shown that there is no significant difference in long-term survival between different surgical methods (such as laparoscopic surgery and open surgery)[50–56], and the key factors for long-term survival may be more dependent on adjuvant therapy, tumor biological characteristics and the overall health status of patients, while the surgical method is only one of many influencing factors[57–62].

Compared with LTG, RTG is superior in terms of short-term efficacy. RTG significantly reduced Clavien–Dindo grade ≥3 complications and abdominal infection, and increased the number of lymph nodes cleared, which may be related to the characteristics of the robotic system itself. Total gastrectomy is recognized as one of the most technically difficult surgeries in gastric cancer surgery, and the high precision and enhanced visualization provided by the robotic system helps physicians better locate the tumor and its infiltrating adjacent tissues for finer anatomy and better control[13,63]. In addition, RTG takes a long time to operate, but for complex procedures, especially those lasting more than 100 minutes, robotic surgical systems can significantly reduce surgeon fatigue, provide more stable support and precise instrument control, and reduce fatigue-related inattention and operational errors[64,65]. Some research is carried out in this field. However, Manara et al’s[66] research focused on open total gastrectomy and rarely mentioned RTG. Jin et al’s[67] research only mentioned RTG in subgroups and was published in 2021. The results need to be updated in a timely manner. The study of Li et al[45] only reported some indicators of RTG in subgroups. The study by Kossenas et al[68] only included five studies, and the outcome indicators only reported postoperative complications. Our research is the most comprehensive comparison of RTG and LTG to date and reports survival indicators.

RTG was also associated with lower surgical blood loss and length of postoperative hospital stay. Intraoperative blood loss was significantly less in the RTG group than in the LTG group (mean 18.103 mL reduction, P < 0.01), but the absolute value of this difference was small and may not be sufficient to independently have a significant clinical impact. The high precision of the robotic system reduces vascular damage, thereby reducing the amount of intraoperative blood loss. Less blood loss and trauma help patients recover quickly after surgery[69]. Although RTG increases surgical time, this is mainly due to the longer preoperative preparation time, and RTG may consume less time than LTG during actual surgery[33]. The total cost results showed that the RTG group spent an average of $3222 more than the LTG group. Although robotic surgery reduces the incidence of complications above grade three, the increased cost is also a notable issue. The huge cost of robots mainly consists of equipment procurement and maintenance expenses. The direct cost of surgery may not be higher than laparoscopic surgery[18]. In the future, with the advancement of technology, the cost of robot surgery may even be lower than that of laparoscopic surgery.

In subgroup analyses, the use of linear staplers was more effective in reducing CD ≥3 complications and length of postoperative hospital stay, consistent with previous findings[70]. The linear stapler can be operated in a limited space and is particularly suitable for the minimally invasive environment of laparoscopic and robotic surgery[71]. With the continuous progress of linear stapler technology, such as the application of innovative technologies such as “Overlap” anastomosis technology and “Later-cut Overlap” method, the anastomosis effect is further optimized and the surgical safety and efficiency are improved, which makes linear stapler more advantageous in complex surgery[72–75]. In subgroup of esophagojejunostomy π – shaped/FEEA/overlap group was more effective in reducing of complications graded as Clavien–Dindo ≥3. However, due to the fact that different esophagojejunostomy techniques were used at different time periods or for different patients in the literature. It is difficult to determine which particular anastomosis method is more conducive to reducing complications graded as Clavien–Dindo ≥3. The postoperative blood loss, postoperative hospital stay, and the time to first exhaust showed a high degree of heterogeneity in the results. We used a random effects model for analysis. Furthermore, we explored the sources of heterogeneity through meta-regression and found that the publication year was the reason for the high heterogeneity of operation time. The results of the sensitivity analysis showed that the postoperative blood loss and the time of first exhaust were relatively reliable. Regarding the postoperative hospital stay, the results should be interpreted with caution.

This study has the following limitations: (1) the included studies were from East Asia and may not be applicable to Western countries; (2) most of the studies were retrospective cohort studies, and although propensity score matching was used, confounding bias may still exist; (3) only a few studies provided HR and 95% confidence intervals. For other studies, the use of Engauge Digitizer v.4.1 software to extract OS and DFS data from survival curves and convert median (range/quartile) continuous variable data to mean and standard deviation may introduce potential errors. (4) Although we attempted to explore the potential sources of heterogeneity through meta-regression analysis, some important confounding factors might not have been fully identified because some studies failed to fully report the key clinical features. Furthermore, the lack of data reports also makes it impossible for some studies to be included in the subgroup analysis. (5) Although the follow-up time of the studies reporting survival indicators all exceeded 36 months, the bias caused by potential differences in the follow-up period could also affect the results. (6) There were no RCTs in the included studies, which might affect the level of evidence.

Despite these limitations, our results still lay a solid foundation for future research endeavors. Currently, robotic surgery is not as widely adopted as laparoscopic surgery. Although our research has indicated that robotic surgery holds potential advantages, these benefits may be further highlighted through larger-scale clinical practice. Single-port laparoscopy has been implemented in some major medical centers. Presently, both robotic and conventional laparoscopic surgeries are multiport procedures. As single-port robotic devices become increasingly equipped in numerous hospitals, the potential advantages of robotic surgery in confined spaces may be further enhanced in the future[76]. Two ongoing high-quality RCTs (NCT03524300, NCT05235982) are anticipated to deliver robust, evidence-based data on surgical interventions for GC and adenocarcinoma of the esophagogastric junction (AEG), potentially refining clinical decision-making in this setting.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: RTG demonstrates superior short-term outcomes compared to LTG, including reduced incidence of severe complications (CD ≥3), lower rates of abdominal infection, decreased intraoperative blood loss, and shorter postoperative hospital stays. In subgroup analysis, linear staplers were more effective than circular staplers in reducing postoperative hospital stay and CD ≥3 complications. Large RCTs with longer follow-up periods are needed in the future to demonstrate the benefit and clinical value of RTG.

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: As this study is based on aggregate data and does not involve humans, ethical approval is not required.

sec.title: Consent
sec.p: Not applicable.

sec.title: Sources of funding
sec.p: This research was funded by the Primary Health Development Research Center of Sichuan Province Program (20240307003), the Sichuan Provincial Medical Research Project (Q23012), and the Science and Technology Program of Nanchong (23JCYJPT0074).

sec.title: Author contributions
sec.p: Q.-J.L., Y.-H.L. contributed to the study design. Y.-H.L., H.-Y.Y., Y.-Q.C., A.B., X.-Y.X., J.Y., H.Z., Y.-T.W., H.A., M.-A.M., analysis of data. Q.-J.L., Y.-H.L., H.-Y.Y., W.Z., H.-W.M., N.-J.C., Z.-N.L., Y.-X.S. wrote the first draft of the manuscript and edited the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest disclosure
sec.p: The authors deny any conflicts of interest.

sec.title: Research registration unique identifying number (UIN)
sec.p: The study was registered with PROSPERO and the registration number is CRD42024618477.

sec.title: Guarantor
sec.p: Qijun Lv.

sec.title: Provenance and peer review
sec.p: Not commissioned, externally peer-reviewed.

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: The datasets used and analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

sec.title: AI usage statemt
sec.p: During the process of manuscript writing, we used the generative artificial intelligence tool DeepSeek-V3 to a limited extent (accessed in May 2025) solely for the purpose of language polishing. After a comprehensive revision of the manuscript, our research team further used the AJE artificial intelligence editing service (https://china.aje.com/en/researcher/submit/get-started) to conduct a thorough review of grammar and formatting and obtain professional evaluations. It is important to note that these AI tools were never employed to generate scientific content, conduct literature searches, analyze data, or derive conclusions. All scientific content, research design, data processing, and interpretation of results were independently completed by the author team. We are well aware of the limitations of AI tools, and all AI-generated revisions were rigorously reviewed and confirmed by the authors to ensure full compliance with journal authorship and academic ethical standards. Additionally, we declare that there is no conflict of interest or financial relationship with the AI service provider.
